results.title: Parents!
results.brief_description: Britannia Butwell believes her parents are embarrassing and wishes for an exchange. That is, until she meets Sandra Sandman. Could Sandra be able to change Britannia’s mind?

results.title: Parents who work
results.creator_credit: Ted Emery, Seven Dimensions and Eve Ash
results.brief_description: Thomas has a sore throat but is sent to school due to his parents’ commitments at the office. Should Dad or Mum have stayed at home? This program looks at parenting and dual responsibility, the importance of forward planning employers’ attitudes to women with families, how and why employers should help and how to negotiate with a partner.

results.title: Parents are people too
results.brief_description: Discusses adolescent feelings of resentment against authority and emphasises the role of the parent, the teacher, and the adolescent himself in resolving differences. Shows how family discussions can replace arguments and help establish good family relations.

results.title: Parenting: stress and the child
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Looks at some potentially stressful family situations for the child, such as the arrival of a baby, entry into a new school, and puberty. Indicates that, although stress is inevitable in children’s lives, once the causes are realised by parents, it can be utilised as a stepping stone towards emotional growth and family unity.

results.title: Parenthood
results.creator_credit: Ron Howard, Brian Grazer and Imagine Entertainment (US)
results.brief_description: Gil Buckman (Steve Martin) and his wife Karen (Mary Steenburgen) are raising three children - high strung Kevin, tomboy Taylor and toddler Justin. When they learn Kevin’s behaviour problems mean he will be held back a year, Gil attempts to become a super-father and solve Kevin’s problems himself. His older sister, Helen (Dianne Wiest), is a single mother raising an introverted son (Joaquin Phoenix) and a promiscuous daughter (Martha Plimpton). Family life isn’t much sweeter for Gil’s younger sister Susan, who is trying to convince her overachiever husband, Nathan (Rick Moranis), that she would like another baby, even though it interferes with the Life Plan he has for their toddler daughter. When the black sheep of the family, Larry (Tom Hulce), shows up unexpectedly with a son of his own, the Buckman’s must all deal with the consequences of their relationships.
